title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON — On a night when offense was at a premium for most, one man operated on a different plane entirely. Juwan Howard didn’t just play a basketball game; he authored a masterpiece, carrying the Washington Bullets to a decisive 106-92 victory over the rival Boston Celtics in 1997.

While the Celtics’ Antoine Walker managed a respectable 19 points, he was a mere spectator to the show Howard put on. The Bullets’ forward was a study in relentless efficiency, pouring in a game-high 42 points. He was unstoppable from the mid-range, a force in the paint, and a model of consistency, hitting 15 of his 26 attempts from the field and converting 12 free throws. This was not a product of volume but of sheer dominance.

Howard’s historic 42-point explosion was the undeniable engine of the Bullets’ win. He didn't just lead the scoring; he *was* the scoring, accounting for nearly 40 percent of his team's total points. His performance lifted the entire roster, as evidenced by Rod Strickland’s 15 assists—many of which likely found Howard for another bucket.

The Celtics, who saw Rick Fox add 16 points, simply had no answer. Every defensive scheme they threw at Howard failed. He dissected them from every spot on the floor, turning a potentially close contest into a one-man showcase.

In the annals of the famed Celtics-Bullets rivalry, this night belongs not to a team, but to one man: Juwan Howard, whose legendary 42-point performance is a benchmark of individual brilliance.
